Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Mobile Drilling Robot for Aerospace Structures Manufacturing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to empower American workers to compete with low-wage workers abroad by providing a lower cost, more flexible way to fabricate complex aerospace structures than labor-intensive manual drilling. Increases in global demand for aircraft are putting pressure on large Original Equipment Manufacturers to increase rates of production. For example: A large aircraft manufacturer increased production of one of their aircraft from 47 to 52 aircraft per month in 2018 and is anticipated to continue to increase this rate to 57 in March 2019. These rate increases are not just putting pressure on the OEMs but also on their sub-tier suppliers who must increase their rates as well. Many of these smaller companies operate on tight budgets in rural areas with smaller employment pools. They are experiencing difficulty keeping up. By enhancing American worker productivity and quality with robotic systems that rural manufacturers can afford, this project will help keep quality manufacturing jobs in America for the next generation.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will design, build and validate a mobile, agile robotic drilling system for aircraft manufacturing. This system will be capable of interfacing with and operating on existing aircraft assembly jigs broadly used in the industry for manual drilling. The system will deliver 90% reduction in drilling cycle time from 60 to six seconds per hole and eliminate repeat motion injury from hand drilling, while eliminating hole quality and positional accuracy defects associated with hand drilled holes. The system will seek to implement human-robot collaboration through a speed-and-separation monitoring approach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During Phase I of the NSF SBIR research grant, Wilder Systems developed a complete Agile Mobile Robot (AMR) for aerospace manufacturing that is currently in production. In addition to the technical development portion of the project Wilder Systems assessed the market need for affordable automation in the aerospace industry to validate commercial viability. The development of the first AMR along with the information gathered from the customer discovery process provided a foundation for Wilder Systems to rapidly scale this technology and provide the benefits of mobile robotic automation that was previously cost prohibitive for aerospace manufacturers in the US.

Wilder Systems rendered a design of an AMR with the ability to utilize a ball-hitch style mechanical coupling system that allows any existing aircraft assembly jig to be made mobile robot-compatible. The design allows the AMR to move on jackable casters and easily used around any production facility. The design enabled technical feasibility of the AMR and allowed the system to be easily implemented into the production system without any major plant modifications.

The AMR system was fabricated to the design specifications and incorporated a speed and separation monitoring safety approach using laser scanners integrated into the mobile robot base. The system was constructed using commercial off the shelf industrial components to keep cost low and allow the Robots as a Service model to be financially viable. After fabrication, the AMR system was rigorously tested on a representative part fixture to assess the positional accuracy and hole quality of the AMR in an identical environment using similar materials. The results of the testing process were able to prove that commercial off the shelf industrial components can be integrated using a sophisticated design to produce a working manufacturing system that meets the quality specifications of custom solutions.

Once the test results met the technical specifications required Wilder Systems validated the performance of a complete mobile system in production on the CH-47 program by drilling over 3,000 holes in a production part. To vet the capabilities of the AMR, we measured hole quality, positional accuracy, and cycle time of the production application and benchmarked against the current manual processes as well as standard metrics for monumental robots. The empirical production data showed that the AMR could indeed meet or beat the production time and quality metrics required for an automated system to be in production for aircraft manufacturing. 

Wilder Systems performed holistic market research by interviewing 32 potential customers in different market segments and presented the findings at “Beat the Odds Boot Camp”. The interviews allowed Wilder Systems to refine the target market and focus our product offering to align with what our potential customers need most. Using the information gathered from the interview process we were able to develop a comprehensive plan for Phase II technical development based on specific potential customer feedback. 

From our Phase I research and development we were able to effectively vet an AMR system ready for commercial and military production at any level of manufacturing. Our learnings allowed us to gain a deep understanding of how to design, build, test, and implement an autonomous system into a previous manual production system where automation was either not physically possible or financially unsustainable. The US aerospace manufacturing industry will greatly benefit from the introduction of affordable automation at the sub tier manufacturing level where production rates are steadily increasing and a limited skilled labor pool is hindering the ability for manufacturers to produce aircraft at cost and on time. The outcome of this project enabled us to further build on the vision of affordable automation for aerospace manufacturing and gave us a clear path for development and what we need to accomplish in Phase II.
